awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I: Novel Adsorbents for Selective Removal of Naturally Occurring Radionuclide Materials (NORM) from Fracking-Produced Water
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to provide a novel and cost-effective technology to remove NORM (Naturally Occurring Radioactive Materials) from the wastewater produced by fracking. The proposed research is of fundamental and practical significance to the area of produced water treatment. The proposed approach seeks to remove 99% of NORM from produced waters effectively, an important advance for environmental treatment. This approach also is expected to reduce the cost of the treatment technology and the associated impact on cost per barrel of gas and oil. 

This STTR Phase I project proposes to verify the effectiveness of new adsorbents waste water clean-up associated with fracking. The geologic formations containing oil and gas deposits contain Naturally Occurring Radionuclide Materials, referred to as NORM.  Oil and gas fracking brings NORM to the surface in a concentrated form, posing a radiation safety hazard. There is currently no commercial product on the market to remove NORM from concentrated produced and flow back water selectively.  By developing theory and computational methods with the Group Contribution method (GCM) and a novel optimization-based Computer-Aided Molecular Design (CAMD) framework, the teams seeks to generate better clay-based adsorbents than are currently commercially available for removal of produced water impurities. The modeling results need to be verified experimentally by synthesizing thenew adsorbents and comparing their adsorption behavior to the theoretically-predicted isotherms before commercializing them.  The research may result in efficient and cost-effective adsorbents customized for the type of water contamination encountered using the new CAMD frameworks and cutting-edge experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Produced water is generated from conventional oil and gas production, as well as the production of unconventional sources such as coal bed methane, tight sands, and gas shale. The geologic formations that contain oil and gas deposits also contain radionuclides, referred to as Naturally Occurring Radioactive Materials (NORM). Oil and gas fracking brings NORM to the surface in a concentrated form, which could pose a radiation safety hazard. In 2011, GTI carried out a Techno-economic Assessment of Water Management Solutions project (2011) supported by 23 companies' consortium. This consortium identified many priority industrial challenges for the pre-and post-crossover stages of a shale gas development area's water-based life cycle and identified NORM removal as one of the highest priority research areas. They also ascertained that there is currently no commercial product on the market to remove NORM from concentrated produced and flowback water selectively. The most common approach to remove NORM from produced water is through co-precipitation with barium sulfate (barite). However, this technology is expensive and generates a significant amount of radioactive waste that must be disposed of. Other technologies for high concentrations of contaminants are energy intensive and are more expensive than co-precipitation.   Through the development of theory and computational methods with the Group Contribution method (GCM) and a novel optimization-based Computer-aided molecular design (CAMD) framework, Dr. Diwekar’s group generated order-of-magnitude better clay-based adsorbents than currently commercially available or published adsorbents for removal of NORM from produced water. The technology is extended to address the problem of Arsenic, Barium, and Strontium, which will make produced water reusable for agriculture. This technology is (1) efficient, (2) easily disposable, (3) safe, (4) cost-effective, and (5) customizable to remove As, Ba, Sr, and Ra from produced water. Concentrations of NORM, Ba, Sr, etc., differ considerably at different parts of the basins. Our technology is uniquely capable of creating customized adsorbents for each region or well, depending on the chemical composition of produced water. The technology is not energy intensive and does not pose scaling or safety concerns. Further, we customize the adsorbents in such a way as to minimize disposal costs. The concept of using CAMD to design novel adsorbents for selectively removing NORM and other contaminants has never been used before.   For example, with our novel adsorbents, we could remove NORM from the produced water with a reported concentration of 1500 to 4000 pCi/l  to an undetectable level. Further, the quantity of absorbent needed to remove NORM is very small, resulting in order of magnitude less material for disposal than the current technology of co-precipitation.

This technology is a disruptive technology that is easy to adopt for these industries without incurring significant costs. The proposed research and development are of considerable fundamental and practical significance to the wastewater and produced water area. The proposal addresses important issues pertaining to the areas of group-contribution methods, computer-aided molecular design, NORM removal, and environmental impacts. On the fundamental side, the contributions of the proposed work are: (1) demonstration of the efficacy of the CAMD approach to developing novel adsorbents for well-defined needs, in this case, NORM removal from different waters, 2) synthesis method for manufacturing of these new adsorbents, and 3) new insights into the interactions at ion-sorbent interfaces that are important in determining adsorption behavior. On the practical side, the problem of NORM is preeminent in Oil & gas industries worldwide. Our unique adsorbent generated by the novel approach of CAMD provides a cost-effective, safe, and customized solution to this ubiquitous problem. The environmental and health effects of NORM are well documented. However, the current restrictions on the re-injection of water due to increased seismic activity demands reusing this water for agriculture, which will directly impact human health.   By removing contaminants like NORM, Arsenic, Barium, and Strontium with our novel adsorbents, the water can be reused for agriculture.

The project involves women researchers. The PI is a woman researcher from engineering. More than 50% of the researchers working with PI have been women and underrepresented minorities.
